title: Ezekiel Chapter 28 Quiz - Multi-Level
description: An enhanced quiz on Ezekiel chapter 28 with Easy, Medium, Hard, and Theological levels. Each level has 15 carefully crafted questions. Choose your difficulty and dive in!

easy.title: Ezekiel Chapter 28 Quiz - Easy Level
easy.description: Perfect for beginners! Test your basic knowledge of Ezekiel Chapter 28.

questions.question: To whom did the word of the LORD come again in Ezekiel 28:1?
questions.correctAnswer: Ezekiel
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 28:1 states, 'The word of the LORD came again unto me,' indicating it was Ezekiel who received the word.

questions.question: According to Ezekiel 28:2, what did the prince of Tyrus say about himself?
questions.correctAnswer: I am a God
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 28:2 says the prince of Tyrus said, 'I am a God, I sit in the seat of God.'

questions.question: Who did God say the prince of Tyrus was wiser than in Ezekiel 28:3?
questions.correctAnswer: Daniel
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 28:3 states, 'Behold, thou art wiser than Daniel;'

questions.question: What treasures did the prince of Tyrus gather according to Ezekiel 28:4?
questions.correctAnswer: Gold and silver
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 28:4 mentions that he gathered 'gold and silver into thy treasures.'

questions.question: What was the reason for the prince of Tyrus's heart being lifted up according to Ezekiel 28:5?
questions.correctAnswer: Because of his riches
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 28:5 says, 'thine heart is lifted up because of thy riches.'

questions.question: What will happen to the prince of Tyrus because he set his heart as the heart of God? (Ezekiel 28:6-7)
questions.correctAnswer: Strangers will come against him
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 28:7 says, 'I will bring strangers upon thee, the terrible of the nations,' because he set his heart as the heart of God.

questions.question: Where will the prince of Tyrus be brought down to according to Ezekiel 28:8?
questions.correctAnswer: The pit
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 28:8 states, 'They shall bring thee down to the pit.'

questions.question: True or False: Ezekiel 28:9 says the prince of Tyrus will be a god in the hand of him that slayeth him.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 28:9 says, 'thou shalt be a man, and no God, in the hand of him that slayeth thee.'

questions.question: According to Ezekiel 28:12, how is the king of Tyrus described?
options: Full of wisdom and perfect in beauty
questions.correctAnswer: Full of wisdom and perfect in beauty
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 28:12 describes the king of Tyrus as 'full of wisdom, and perfect in beauty.'

questions.question: Fill in the blank: According to Ezekiel 28:13, the king of Tyrus was covered with every precious stone, including the _______, topaz, and the diamond.
questions.correctAnswer: sardius
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 28:13 lists 'the sardius, topaz, and the diamond' as part of the precious stones covering him.

questions.question: What was the king of Tyrus's role as described in Ezekiel 28:14?
questions.correctAnswer: The anointed cherub that covereth
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 28:14 states, 'Thou art the anointed cherub that covereth.'

questions.question: True or False: Ezekiel 28:15 states the king of Tyrus was perfect in his ways from creation until iniquity was found in him.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 28:15 says, 'Thou wast perfect in thy ways from the day that thou wast created, till iniquity was found in thee.'

questions.question: What caused the king of Tyrus to be cast out according to Ezekiel 28:16?
options: The multitude of his merchandise and sin
questions.correctAnswer: The multitude of his merchandise and sin
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 28:16 says, 'By the multitude of thy merchandise... thou hast sinned: therefore I will cast thee as profane out of the mountain of God.'

questions.question: What was the cause of the king of Tyrus's corruption mentioned in Ezekiel 28:17?
options: His heart was lifted up because of his beauty
questions.correctAnswer: His heart was lifted up because of his beauty
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 28:17 states, 'Thine heart was lifted up because of thy beauty, thou hast corrupted thy wisdom.'

questions.question: True or False: Ezekiel 28:19 states that the king of Tyrus will never be any more and will be a terror.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 28:19 says, 'thou shalt be a terror, and never shalt thou be any more.'

medium.title: Ezekiel Chapter 28 Quiz - Medium Level
medium.description: Ready for more? Apply biblical truths from Ezekiel Chapter 28 to real-life situations.

questions.question: A fellow believer is struggling with pride and arrogance in their work achievements. Based on Ezekiel 28, what biblical truth would you share about humility?
options: Pride leads to downfall because God opposes the proud
Riches and wisdom guarantee God's favor
Elevating oneself as God is acceptable if done wisely
questions.correctAnswer: Pride leads to downfall because God opposes the proud
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 28:2-6 and 17 show that pride and setting one's heart as God’s heart leads to judgment and downfall. The prince of Tyre's pride in his wisdom and riches brought destruction.

questions.question: How does Ezekiel 28 teach about trust in God's sovereignty when facing opposition and trials?
options: God will bring strangers and enemies against the proud to humble them
We must rely only on our own wisdom to overcome struggles
We can become gods by our own strength
Opposition is a sign of God's rejection
questions.correctAnswer: God will bring strangers and enemies against the proud to humble them
questions.explanation: Verses 7-10 reveal that God brings enemies against the proud prince to humble him, showing God's control over circumstances to discipline and teach obedience.

questions.question: A believer is tempted to trust in their material wealth for security. What guidance does Ezekiel 28 provide about riches and contentment?
options: Riches gained by wisdom can lead to pride and destruction
Wealth is a sure sign of God's unconditional blessing
Ignoring wealth is the only way to be righteous
questions.correctAnswer: Riches gained by wisdom can lead to pride and destruction
questions.explanation: Verses 4-6 show the prince of Tyre gained riches through wisdom but his heart was lifted up, leading to his ruin. This warns against trusting in wealth rather than God.

questions.question: What does Ezekiel 28 teach about the importance of recognizing human limitations compared to God?
options: Though wise, the prince of Tyre was still a man and not God
Human beings can achieve godlike status through wisdom
Man's heart is equal to God's heart
No one is accountable for claiming divine status
questions.correctAnswer: Though wise, the prince of Tyre was still a man and not God
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 28:2-3 emphasizes that despite his wisdom and claims, the prince was only a man and not God, teaching humility and recognition of God's unique nature.

questions.question: How does this passage highlight the consequences of corrupt business practices on spiritual life?
options: The prince defiled his sanctuaries through iniquity and traffick
Financial gain is unrelated to spiritual condition
Corruption is justified if it leads to riches
questions.correctAnswer: The prince defiled his sanctuaries through iniquity and traffick
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 28:18 connects the prince's sinful trade practices with defiling sanctuaries, showing that dishonesty harms spiritual standing and invites judgment.

questions.question: A believer feels tempted to boast about their wisdom and achievements. Based on Ezekiel 28, what biblical principle should be applied?
options: Boasting leads to pride which causes downfall
Boasting is encouraged to inspire others
questions.correctAnswer: Boasting leads to pride which causes downfall
questions.explanation: Verses 2, 17 stress how the prince's lifted heart and boasting led to corruption and downfall, teaching the virtue of humility and reliance on God.

questions.question: What does Ezekiel 28 reveal about God's judgment on those who exalt themselves and reject His authority?
options: God will bring them down and expose them publicly
questions.correctAnswer: God will bring them down and expose them publicly
questions.explanation: Verses 16-17 describe God casting the covering cherub down and laying him before kings to be seen, illustrating public exposure and judgment on pride.

questions.question: How does Ezekiel 28 encourage believers to respond to trials and opposition from others?
options: Trust that God will execute justice and sanctify His people
Rely on personal strength alone to survive
questions.correctAnswer: Trust that God will execute justice and sanctify His people
questions.explanation: Verses 22-26 assure that God will judge nations like Zidon and protect Israel, encouraging believers to trust God's justice amid trials.

questions.question: True or False: According to Ezekiel 28, the prince of Tyre was perfect in his ways from creation until iniquity was found in him.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 28:15 states the prince was perfect until iniquity was found, highlighting the fall from initial perfection due to sin.

questions.question: True or False: Ezekiel 28 teaches that God’s people will eventually live safely and confidently after God executes judgment on their enemies.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Verses 25-26 describe God gathering Israel and ensuring their safety and confidence once judgment on their enemies is executed.

questions.question: The prince of Tyre claimed, "I am a God, I sit in the seat of God, in the midst of the seas." This statement teaches us about the danger of _________.
questions.correctAnswer: pride and arrogance
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 28:2 shows the prince’s claim as prideful arrogance that God condemns, illustrating the spiritual danger of self-exaltation.

questions.question: How does Ezekiel 28 illustrate the importance of integrity in one's dealings and stewardship?
options: Dishonest traffick defiles sanctuaries and brings judgment
Integrity is irrelevant to spiritual condition
Stewardship is only about accumulating wealth
Dishonesty in business is acceptable if successful
questions.correctAnswer: Dishonest traffick defiles sanctuaries and brings judgment
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 28:18 links the prince's corrupt trade to defiling sanctuaries and divine judgment, underscoring integrity’s role in spiritual life.

questions.question: What spiritual discipline can we learn from the prince of Tyre's downfall in Ezekiel 28?
options: Guarding against pride and maintaining humility
Seeking to be seen as wise by all
Setting one’s heart as God’s heart independently
Trusting in personal riches for security
questions.correctAnswer: Guarding against pride and maintaining humility
questions.explanation: Verses 2, 15-17 show the prince’s pride led to his ruin, teaching the need for humility and dependence on God’s grace.

questions.question: A believer is facing temptation to elevate themselves above others. How does Ezekiel 28 guide us to deal with such temptation?
options: Remember that God opposes the proud and brings them low
questions.correctAnswer: Remember that God opposes the proud and brings them low
questions.explanation: The passage (Ezekiel 28:6-9) warns that pride causes God to bring judgment and humiliation, urging believers to resist pride.

questions.question: How does Ezekiel 28 encourage believers to have confidence in God during times of persecution or hardship?
options: God will sanctify His people and execute judgment on oppressors
Hardships mean God has abandoned His people
Believers should rely on their own strength only
Suffering is to be avoided at all costs
questions.correctAnswer: God will sanctify His people and execute judgment on oppressors
questions.explanation: Verses 22-26 emphasize God’s promise to sanctify Israel and judge those who despise them, encouraging confidence in God’s justice.

hard.title: Ezekiel Chapter 28 Quiz - Hard Level
hard.description: Challenge yourself with deep analysis and cross-biblical connections from Ezekiel Chapter 28.

questions.question: In Ezekiel 28, the prince of Tyre is compared to which biblical figure in terms of wisdom?
questions.correctAnswer: Daniel
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 28:3 states that the prince of Tyre is wiser than Daniel, highlighting his great wisdom.

questions.question: What is the main reason given for the downfall of the prince of Tyre according to Ezekiel 28?
options: His arrogance and claiming to be God
questions.correctAnswer: His arrogance and claiming to be God
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 28:2 and 6 explain that because his heart is lifted up and he claims to be God, judgment is pronounced upon him.

questions.question: Ezekiel 28:13 lists precious stones as the covering of the king of Tyre. Which of the following stones is NOT mentioned in this verse?
questions.correctAnswer: Ruby
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 28:13 mentions sardius, topaz, diamond, beryl, onyx, jasper, sapphire, emerald, carbuncle, and gold, but not ruby.

questions.question: The figure described in Ezekiel 28:14 as the 'anointed cherub that covereth' is often interpreted as a typology for which biblical figure?
questions.correctAnswer: Satan
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 28:14-16 uses language and imagery traditionally associated with the fall of a perfect being, commonly interpreted as Satan before his fall.

questions.question: Which literary device is prominently used in Ezekiel 28 when addressing both the prince of Tyre and the king of Tyre in parallel sections?
questions.correctAnswer: Chiasm
questions.explanation: The chapter uses a chiasm structure contrasting the human ruler and a divine or angelic figure to emphasize themes of pride and downfall.

questions.question: In Ezekiel 28:17, what is the cause of corruption and downfall of the cherub described?
questions.correctAnswer: Pride because of his beauty
questions.explanation: Verse 17 states that the cherub's heart was lifted up because of his beauty, leading to corrupted wisdom and downfall.

questions.question: Ezekiel 28:18 speaks of fire coming forth from the cherub. This imagery is an example of which biblical theme?
questions.correctAnswer: Divine judgment
questions.explanation: The fire devouring the cherub symbolizes God's judgment and destruction due to sin and iniquity.

questions.question: What does Ezekiel 28:12 mean by saying the king of Tyre 'sealest up the sum, full of wisdom, and perfect in beauty'?
options: He is portrayed as an ideal or archetype of perfection
He is a skilled seal engraver
questions.correctAnswer: He is portrayed as an ideal or archetype of perfection
questions.explanation: This phrase uses metaphorical language to symbolize the king’s perfection and wisdom before his fall.

questions.question: According to Ezekiel 28, what will happen to the prince of Tyre after strangers come against him?
options: He will die the deaths of the slain in the midst of the seas
He will escape to another land
He will repent and be restored
He will be imprisoned for life
questions.correctAnswer: He will die the deaths of the slain in the midst of the seas
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 28:8 states that strangers will bring him down to the pit and he will die like those slain in the seas.

questions.question: Ezekiel 28:21-24 prophesies against which city, emphasizing God's judgment through pestilence and blood in its streets?
questions.correctAnswer: Zidon
questions.explanation: These verses explicitly address Zidon and proclaim judgment against it with pestilence and bloodshed.

questions.question: True or False: The chapter portrays the prince of Tyre as literally being God.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 28:2 and 9 emphasize that though the prince says 'I am a God,' he is only a man and not God.

questions.question: Ezekiel 28:25-26 describes the restoration of which people group to their land?
questions.correctAnswer: The house of Israel
questions.explanation: These verses promise that God will gather Israel from the nations and they will dwell safely in their land.

questions.question: The phrase 'the holy mountain of God' in Ezekiel 28:14 is an allusion that most likely refers to what location?
questions.correctAnswer: Mount Zion in Jerusalem
questions.explanation: In biblical literature, 'the holy mountain of God' often refers to Mount Zion, the symbolic dwelling place of God’s presence.

questions.question: What is the significance of the 'stones of fire' mentioned in Ezekiel 28:14 and 16?
options: They symbolize divine presence and purity
They represent the wealth of Tyre
They refer to the weapons of war
questions.correctAnswer: They symbolize divine presence and purity
questions.explanation: The imagery of 'stones of fire' is symbolic of God's holy presence and the purity that the cherub once had before sin.

questions.question: Ezekiel 28:4-5 connects the prince of Tyre’s wisdom and understanding to what primary activity?
questions.correctAnswer: Acquiring riches through trade
questions.explanation: Verses 4-5 describe how the prince increased riches by wisdom and traffick (trade), leading to his pride.

theological.title: Ezekiel Chapter 28 Quiz - Theological Level
theological.description: Deep biblical theology from Ezekiel Chapter 28 that unites all believers. Explore foundational truths about God, creation, and humanity.

questions.question: According to Ezekiel 28, why does God pronounce judgment on the prince of Tyrus?
options: Because his heart is lifted up and he claims to be God
Because he refuses to pay tribute
questions.correctAnswer: Because his heart is lifted up and he claims to be God
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 28:2 states that the prince of Tyrus has a heart lifted up and says, 'I am a God,' which is the reason for God's judgment. This reflects the biblical theme against pride and blasphemy seen in Isaiah 14:13-14, 1 Timothy 3:6, James 4:6, and Proverbs 16:18.

questions.question: What does Ezekiel say about the wisdom of the prince of Tyrus in comparison to Daniel?
options: He is less wise than Daniel
He is equally wise as Daniel
questions.correctAnswer: He is wiser than Daniel
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 28:3 says, 'Behold, thou art wiser than Daniel,' emphasizing the prince's great wisdom. This serves to highlight his pride and self-exaltation. Daniel is a biblical symbol of wisdom (Daniel 1:17, 2:20), so surpassing him implies extreme arrogance. The Bible consistently warns against pride in wisdom (Proverbs 3:7, 1 Corinthians 1:25).

questions.question: What consequence does God say will come upon the prince of Tyrus because of his lifted-up heart and wealth?
options: Strangers will bring him down and he will die
He will become king of many nations
questions.correctAnswer: Strangers will bring him down and he will die
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 28:7-8 declares that strangers will come against him, defile his wisdom, and bring him down to the pit where he will die. This judgment reveals the biblical principle that pride leads to downfall (Proverbs 16:18, Luke 14:11, James 4:10).

questions.question: In Ezekiel 28, what does God say about the true nature of the prince of Tyrus despite his claims?
options: He is a man and not God
He is a god in human form
questions.correctAnswer: He is a man and not God
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 28:2 and 9 affirm that though he sets his heart as the heart of God, he remains a man and not God. This underscores the biblical doctrine of the uniqueness of God (Deuteronomy 6:4, Isaiah 45:5, John 1:1, Colossians 1:16).

questions.question: Who is addressed in the lamentation that Ezekiel is told to take up in Ezekiel 28:12-19?
questions.correctAnswer: The king of Tyrus
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 28:12 commands to take up a lamentation upon the king of Tyrus, describing his former perfection and subsequent fall. This lament illustrates God's judgment on pride and sin, similar to Isaiah 14's lament on the king of Babylon and the fall of Lucifer (Isaiah 14:12-15, Luke 10:18).

questions.question: What does Ezekiel 28 say about the king of Tyrus' original state before his fall?
options: He was in Eden, full of wisdom and perfect in beauty
He was a fallen angel from the beginning
He was a poor man who gained wealth
He was a prophet of God
questions.correctAnswer: He was in Eden, full of wisdom and perfect in beauty
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 28:13-15 describes the king of Tyrus as being in Eden, adorned with precious stones, perfect in ways until iniquity was found in him. This language echoes the description of Lucifer's original state (Isaiah 14:12-15, Genesis 2:8-9, Job 38:7), symbolizing his exaltation and fall.

questions.question: What role does the king of Tyrus hold according to Ezekiel 28:14?
questions.correctAnswer: Anointed cherub that covereth
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 28:14 calls him the 'anointed cherub that covereth,' indicating a high angelic or symbolic status before his fall. This reflects Christological and angelological themes, paralleling descriptions of angelic beings in Isaiah 6:2, Revelation 4:6-8, and the fall of Satan (Luke 10:18).

questions.question: What caused the fall of the king of Tyrus, as stated in Ezekiel 28?
options: Iniquity was found in him due to pride and corrupted wisdom
questions.correctAnswer: Iniquity was found in him due to pride and corrupted wisdom
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 28:15-17 explains that iniquity was found in him because his heart was lifted up due to beauty and wisdom corruption. This illustrates the biblical principle that pride leads to sin and judgment (Proverbs 16:18, Isaiah 14:13-15, 1 Timothy 3:6).

questions.question: How does God describe the judgment upon the king of Tyrus in Ezekiel 28:18?
options: Fire will come forth and devour him, turning him to ashes
He will be exiled to a distant land
He will be forgiven after repentance
questions.correctAnswer: Fire will come forth and devour him, turning him to ashes
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 28:18 declares that fire will come from within him, devouring him to ashes before all who see. This imagery aligns with divine judgment by fire in Scripture (Malachi 4:1, 2 Thessalonians 1:8, Revelation 20:9-10).

questions.question: What future effect does Ezekiel say the destruction of the king of Tyrus will have on those who know him?
options: They will be astonished and he will be a terror never to be again
They will worship him as a god
questions.correctAnswer: They will be astonished and he will be a terror never to be again
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 28:19 states those who know him will be astonished, and he will become a terror, never to exist again. This portrays the finality of judgment, consistent with prophetic warnings (Psalm 37:10, Isaiah 13:9, Revelation 20:10).

questions.question: What city is prophesied against after the king of Tyrus in Ezekiel 28?
questions.correctAnswer: Zidon
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 28:21 commands to set the face against Zidon and prophesy against it, signaling God’s judgment on this city as well. This fits the biblical pattern of prophetic oracles against cities (Jeremiah 25:22, Amos 1:9, Zephaniah 2:4).

questions.question: What judgments will God execute upon Zidon as announced in Ezekiel 28:23?
options: Pestilence, bloodshed, and sword in the streets
questions.correctAnswer: Pestilence, bloodshed, and sword in the streets
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 28:23 prophesies pestilence, blood in the streets, and sword judgment upon Zidon, reflecting God's severe punishment for sin as seen in other prophetic judgments (Jeremiah 21:7, Ezekiel 5:12, Revelation 6:8).

questions.question: What future hope does God reveal concerning Israel in Ezekiel 28:24-26?
options: Israel will be gathered, sanctified, and dwell safely in their land
Israel will be destroyed for their sins
Israel will rule over all nations immediately
questions.correctAnswer: Israel will be gathered, sanctified, and dwell safely in their land
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 28:24-26 promises God will gather Israel, sanctify them, and allow them to dwell safely with confidence. This eschatological hope aligns with God's covenant faithfulness (Jeremiah 31:10-14, Isaiah 11:11-12, Romans 11:26).

questions.question: How is God’s holiness and sovereignty demonstrated in His judgment upon Tyrus and Zidon in Ezekiel 28?
options: By executing judgments to be sanctified and glorified in them
By allowing them to conquer Israel
By remaining silent to their sins
questions.correctAnswer: By executing judgments to be sanctified and glorified in them
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 28:22 states God will be glorified and sanctified through His judgments, showing His holiness and sovereignty in punishing sin. This theme is central in Scripture (Exodus 34:14, Isaiah 6:3, Romans 3:25-26, Revelation 15:4).

questions.question: What does Ezekiel 28 reveal about the relationship between wisdom, pride, and sin?
options: Great wisdom can lead to pride, which results in sin and downfall
Wisdom always prevents sin and pride
Sin leads to wisdom and humility
questions.correctAnswer: Great wisdom can lead to pride, which results in sin and downfall
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 28:4-5 and 17 link the prince's great wisdom and riches to lifted-up heart and corrupted wisdom, leading to sin. This theological principle is echoed in Proverbs 16:18, Isaiah 14:12-15, and James 4:6.
